subject: OS-5543 Deliver the ACPI debugging tools Reviewed by: Patrick Mooney <patrick.mooney@joyent.com> Reviewed by: Robert Mustacchi <rm@joyent.com>
commitMessage:
OS-5543 Deliver the ACPI debugging tools
Reviewed by: Patrick Mooney <patrick.mooney@joyent.com>
Reviewed by: Robert Mustacchi <rm@joyent.com>

comments.message:
Patch Set 1:

Only the following files should be reviewed:
exception_lists/cddlchk
exception_lists/copyright
exception_lists/cstyle
exception_lists/hdrchk
manifest
usr/src/cmd/Makefile
usr/src/cmd/acpi/Makefile
usr/src/cmd/acpi/acpidump/Makefile
usr/src/cmd/acpi/acpidump/Readme
usr/src/cmd/acpi/acpidump/osillumostbl.c
usr/src/cmd/acpi/common/Makefile
usr/src/cmd/acpi/common/osl.c
usr/src/man/man1m/Makefile
usr/src/man/man1m/acpidump.1m
usr/src/man/man1m/acpixtract.1m
usr/src/uts/intel/sys/acpi/platform/acsolaris.h

Patch Set 1:

(30 comments)

responded to comments, uploading a new review

Patch Set 2:

(20 comments)

The code in general looks pretty good, but the manual pages are almost there, just need a little bit more polish.

Patch Set 2:

(20 comments)

I fixed the man pages. I also added a Readme that refers to the kernel source code.

Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

Thanks for all the work here!

Patch Set 4:

Added the requested comment
Change has been successfully merged by Jerry Jelinek
Is there a reason we're not making this file C-style clean?

Well, 90% of it is unchanged from the original Intel file and I was hoping to avoid touching every line, but since I made an illumos-specific version now, I guess that means I need to make it clean, so I rewrote the entire file.
Surely we have a PATH_MAX definition, no?
Why do we only increment by one in this if statement, seems like we'll loop here forever. Or is this how it came from ACPI?
It came this way and you can also see that this not what control loop termination.
Won't this always fire if a user has a non-zero instance, even if we actually match it?
Yes, but all of the callers only ever passed in 0, so I removed that parameter and this code.
Does this note apply to us?
Should we be worrying about overflow here or in the else case below for NumberOfTables due to truncation?
I changed this to a full-size int
Same comment on NumberOfTables above. Also applies below.
Is it worth some sort of guard to make sure this gets updated if it's ever change to accidentally build with FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64?
I added a cast since this code explicitly only does 32-bit
done as part of making all of this cstyle clean
Presumably this needs to be cleaned up?
oops, yeah, sorry, thanks for catching it
Why do we MAP_NORESERVE here? Is this required by /dev/xsvc?
It appears to be since things didn't work right without that. This is also how the old opensolaris code did it.
Can't we actually calculate the offset here? Though I agree that it's probably not the biggest deal here.
I don't see calls to AcpiOsTerminate, AcpiOsCreateLock or AcpiOsDeleteLock anywhere in the userspace code.  Are they necessary to define here?

While it looks like the userspace code is only using AcpiOsAcquireLock/ReleaseLock to serialize file writes, wouldn't we want to use mutex_enter/mutex_leave here?  (It may also involve a define so that ACPI_SPINLOCK is translated into an appropriate type for the handle.

All of this user-land code is single threaded. The only reason we have these is because some of the code is the same as what is compiled into the kernel and it is written with that in mind. Thus, there is no reason for a mutex in these utilities.
Could you add that as a comment here so later readers are similarly confused?
Can we try and convert these new manual pages to mdoc?
This description feels incomplete. This doesn't tell me anything very useful beyond what the NAME did. Talking about how it gets data from the running system, what it does with it, etc. might help.
I don't think we need an ACPI debugging tutorial here. If you need this utility, you know what it does.
How are the binary files specified?
Perhaps print the help / usage message and exists. Help on its own isn't very friendly.
How is the input name specified, this appears to take no arguments.
How is the output file specified, this appears to take no arguments?
How is the RSDP specified, it appears to take no arguments.
Can this be more explicit about the implications?
What would like it to say? See my comment about an ACPI debugging tutorial.
Can this be converted to mdoc?
Is this synopsis correct? Does it read from standard in and then write out to standard out?
This description can be improved. How do I get these dumps, maybe acpidump? Where do the data dumps go? Is there any format to them?
As opposed to what default behavior?
How is the signature specified? This suggests there's no argument to this.
I did a quick survey of several commands in section 1m and none of them had an interface stability. This seems meaningless to me in the illumos world in any case.
Can we s/BIOS/ACPI. Also, I'm afraid of the horses that the BIOS has.

How about:

The
.Nm
utility is used to dump the system's Advanced Configuration and Power Interface (ACPI) tables provided by system firmware. The dumped tables can be used by other utilities like
.Xr acpiextract 1M
or other ACPI-related tools like
.Sy iasl .

Conventionally when these take an argument, we include that here. So for example, you'd want to use the line:

.It Fl a Ar address

to describe the argument. The same is true for most of the others here which take arguments. I'd suggest looking at the ctfdump manual page.

You want .Ar, not .Nm. this is true in most every place except in the SYNOPSIS section. The purpose of .Nm is to be the document's name, so it might show as acpidump or something else. You can use .Ar for the things which are the arguments to flags.
I'd recommend using .Sy here, to basically stress the symbol.

Can we change the first sentence to:

The
.Nm
utility extracts the binary data from a dump of the system's Advanced Configuration and Power Interface (ACPI) tables.
This is probably a different flag from -h.

I think this wants to be:

.It Fl s Ar signature
Looks like this still needs to be converted to .Sy.
Looks like this still needs to be converted to .Sy.
